name: Chapter 3: Amazon EC2 Pricing Models
description: Flashcards explaining different EC2 pricing models through real-world pizza kitchen metaphors.

cards.front: You have an unpredictable workload and want to avoid long-term commitments. Which EC2 pricing model fits?
cards.back: On-Demand Instances let you pay only for compute capacity used, without upfront costs or commitments—ideal for short-term or variable workloads.
cards.example: A developer launches test environments with EC2 On-Demand for a few hours each week.
cards.mnemonic: Pay as you bake. No strings, no stress.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: EC2 pricing model where you pay by the hour or second with no long-term commitment.

cards.front: You plan to run workloads consistently over the next year. Which pricing model offers savings without tying you to specific instance types?
cards.back: Amazon EC2 Savings Plans offer lower prices when you commit to consistent usage (e.g., $10/hour) for 1 or 3 years, across EC2 instance families.
cards.example: A SaaS company commits to $100/hr of compute usage, receiving discounts across all EC2 instance types.
cards.mnemonic: Commit to bake, and save your cake.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: A flexible pricing model that offers discounts in exchange for a usage commitment.

cards.front: You want to reserve a specific EC2 instance for predictable, long-term workloads. Which model applies?
cards.back: Reserved Instances allow you to reserve specific EC2 instance types for 1 or 3 years at a discounted rate—ideal for steady-state workloads.
cards.example: A company reserves m5.large instances for a 3-year database deployment, saving over 70%.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: EC2 pricing option with cost savings for long-term commitments on specific instance types.

cards.front: You’re running a flexible workload and want the lowest cost, even if interrupted. What EC2 pricing model fits?
cards.back: Spot Instances let you use spare EC2 capacity at up to 90% off, but can be interrupted when AWS needs the capacity back.
cards.example: A data processing job runs on Spot Instances, restarting only if interrupted by AWS reclaiming the capacity.
cards.mnemonic: Cheap heat—but you might get beat.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: EC2 option using unused capacity at a discount, with the risk of interruption.

cards.front: Your application requires physical isolation for compliance. Which EC2 pricing model ensures full control over the server?
cards.back: Dedicated Hosts provide physical EC2 servers for your exclusive use, enabling you to meet licensing or compliance requirements.
cards.example: A healthcare provider uses Dedicated Hosts to comply with regulatory rules requiring isolated environments.
cards.mnemonic: Your kitchen, your rules—but at a premium.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: Physical EC2 servers allocated to a single customer for greater control and compliance.
